topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic struct-d) (topic firmware-d) (topic pmcrevhis-d) a(props sp-version) a(props pmc_switch) a(props pmc_package) a(props pmc_phy) a(props ddr-width) a(props package) a(props fw_package) a(props pcie-drive-ports ) a(props pcie-host-ports) a(props raid-support ) a(props sas-ports ) a(props media) a(props component)
topic.title: Modes of operation and examples

body.p: The SDK supports two methods for assigning ODTUjk multiplexing instances to MO ODUk signals when multiplexing LO ODUk signals from a ODUCn MO ODUk is required: automatic assignment by the SDK and manual assignment managed by the network management system (NMS). This section describes the organization of the ODTUjk multiplexing instances with example blocking and non-blocking examples for OTUCn low order ODTUjk multiplexing. The LO ODUCn multiplexing capacity and system design implications when using automatic and manual modes are described including software sequences. Examples for OTU4 multiplexing options are provided that illustrate the implications for support 500G and 600G of line side OTUCn / OTU4 processing when LO ODTUjk multiplexing is enabled for the OTU4.

Figure 1 illustrates the organization of the ODUCn and ODTUjk multiplexing instances along with the supported datapaths for OTUCn and OTU4 signals. The diagram is annotated with the HO/MO/LO nomenclature that is used throughout this document for ODUCn and ODUk signals. Any one of the six ODTUjk multiplexing instances can be configured to support a maximum of 100G of second stage ODTUjk multiplexing for OTU4/ODU4 signals only and ODUCn is not supported for datapaths to the map OTN block or Interlaken as illustrated by the blue paths. The system OTN and map OTN blocks each support up to 600G of capacity but share a 600G ODUk switch port and the Interlaken interface supports up to 500G of ODUk traffic.

fig.title: OTN Multiplexing Support for OTUk and OTUCn Signals

body.p: Figure 2 illustrates the multiplexing support for OTUCn signals. The device supports one and two stages of multiplexing for ODUCn. One stage multiplexing supports ODUCn (n=1 to 6) HO <> ODUj (up to 60 channels) MO. The ODUCn multiplexing block performs the ODTUCn.ts multiplexing and the LO ODTUjk multiplexing instances are bypassed (not illustrated). Two stages of multiplexing supports ODUCn (n=1 to 6) HO <> ODUk (up to 60 channels) MO <> ODUj (up to 190 channels) LO. The ODUCn multiplexing block performs the ODTUCn.ts multiplexing and and the LO ODTUjk multiplexing instances are configured as ODTUjk.ts. A regeneration path for ODUCn from the line OTN to the system OTN subsystem is supported (n=1 to 6). ODUCn to Interlaken and the map OTN subsystem is not supported.

fig.title: OTN Multiplexing Support for OTUCn Signals

body.p: Figure 3 illustrates the multiplexing support for OTU4 signals and Figure 4 illustrates the multiplexing support for OTU4+ signals. The device supports one and two stages of multiplexing for ODU4/4+. One stage multiplexing supports ODk (k= 4 or 4+, up to 6 channels) HO <> ODUj (up to 190 channels) MO. The HO multiplexing block is configured as ODTUjk.ts (k=4 or 4+). Two stages of multiplexing support is as follows.

li.p: ODU4 (up to 5 channels) <> ODUk (100G, up to 40 channels) <> ODUj (up to 190 channels)
500G configured as ODU4 <> ODUj, HO MUX is configured as ODTUjk.ts (k=4)
100G configured as ODU4 <> ODUk <> ODUj, LO MUX is configured as ODTUjk.ts (up to 100G)
ODU4+ processed as a HO ODUk with one or two stages of multiplexing

body.p: ODU4/4+ regeneration or transponders (line OTN to system OTN) and ODU4/4+ to Interlaken is supported. ODU4+ to the map OTN subsystem is not supported. Note the Interlaken interface is limited to 500G of ODUk traffic and a maximum of 190 channels.

fig.title: OTN Multiplexing Support for OTU4 Signals
OTN Multiplexing Support for OTU4+ Signals

body.p: As an example of how a blocking scenario could occur when manually allocating the ODTUjk multiplexing instances to a ODUCn, consider the day 1 scenario of Figure 5. An ODUC6 contains 42 x ODU2 or a total LO use of 420G which exceeds the 300G non-blocking capacity of the automatic method for allocating ODTUjk multiplexing instances but is within the total capacity of 600G. Over the course of provisioning, the NMS may have manually provisioned each 100G JK multiplexing instance to mux 7 x ODU2. On day 2, an attempt is made to provision an ODU4 as illustrated in Figure 6. The capacity exists to add the 100G of bandwidth since only 420G of the 600G is used and 180G is available but each ODTUjk multiplexing instance has 56 of 96 tributary slots allocated such that provisioning another ODU4 is blocked. In this case, rearrangement is required to de-provision 5 x ODU2 from one ODTUjk multiplexing instance and re-provision to the other instances to make room for the ODU4.

fig.title: ODUC6 LO Multiplexing Blocking Example - Day 1
ODUC6 LO Multiplexing Blocking Example - Day 2

body.p: Figure 7 illustrates a similar ODUC6 non-blocking example where the device SDK is used to automatically allocate ODTUjk multiplexing instances to OTUCn and OTU4 signals. In this example, all six ODTUjk multiplexing instances are allocated to the OTUC6 as per the allocation rules of Table 1.

fig.title: ODUC6 LO Multiplexing Non-blocking Example JK Mux Allocation

body.p: Figure 8 illustrates a ODUC6 non-blocking example where the ODUC6 contains 6 x ODU2 and 5 x ODU3 for a total capacity of 260G on day 1. On day 2 an ODU3 is added as shown in Figure 9. The device SDK guarantees 300G non-blocking LO capacity over any ordering of LO ODUk provisioning and de-provisioning and ODUk signals of different types. Six 100G ODTUjk multiplexing instances are used to ensure LO ODUk capacity up to 300G can always be hitlessly provisioned without re-arrangement of already provisioned resources.

fig.title: ODUC6 LO Multiplexing Non-blocking Example JK Mux Allocation - Day 1
ODUC6 LO Multiplexing Non-blocking Example JK Mux Allocation - Day 2

body.p: Figure 10 illustrates an example of the ODTUjk multiplexing instance allocation for a mix of OTUC3 and 2x OTU4 signals where the SDK is automatically allocating the ODTUjk multiplexing resources. In this example, the SDK allocates three ODTUjk multiplexing instances for the OTUC3 to support 200G of non-blocking LO multiplexing . Three ODTUjk multiplexing instances are allocated to the 2 x OTU4 signals for 200G of MO ODUk multiplexing and 100G of LO ODTUjk multiplexing where 100G of LO ODUk can be from any of the 200G of MO ODUk. The allocation of ODTUjk multiplexing instances is consistent with Table 1 for the case where 100G of LO ODU4 multiplexing is used. Note the application is limited to 500G of line side capacity with LO ODTUjk multiplexing since all the logical ODTUjk multiplexing instances are allocated.

fig.title: 500G Mixed OTUCn and OTU4 Use Case with Automatic SDK Allocation of JK Multiplexing Resources and 2 Stage OTU4/ODU4 Multiplexing

body.p: Figure 11 illustrates an example similar to Figure 10 except LO ODTUjk multiplexing is not supported for the OTU4/ODU4 signals. In this case, an additional line side OTU4 with MO ODTUjk multiplexing is supported for a total of 600G of line side interfaces.

fig.title: 600G Mixed OTUCn and OTU4 Use Case with Automatic SDK Allocation of JK Multiplexing Resources without 2 Stage OTU4/ODU4 Multiplexing

body.p: Mid order ODUk signals from a HO ODUCn are presented to the ODTUjk multiplexing instances for multiplexing / de-multiplexing LO ODUk signals. Each ODTUjk multiplexing instance can process any of the MO ODUk signals. Blocking scenarios for provisioning the LO ODUk can result from the ODTUjk multiplexing boundaries for each instance as noted in the examples above. The SDK always assigns the same ODTUjk multiplexing instances to an OTUCn group. The physical resource associated with the logical resource is managed by the SDK and is not visible to the NMS. The logical JK multiplexing instance used to process a specific MO ODUk is either selected by the SDK (automatic assignment) or can be specified by the NMS (referred to as manual or explicit assignment).

Use automatic assignment when the MO ODUk composition of the ODUCn is arbitrary (e.g. ODU2, ODU3, ODU4, OD0, etc.) or contains ODUk signals of the same type. Automatic assignment with an arbitrary composition of MO ODUk signals guarantees assignment of the ODTUjk multiplexing instances by the SDK will not block LO multiplexing regardless of the provisioning and de-provisioning sequence of the MO ODUk and LO ODUk signals. The limitation is the ODUCn non-blocking LO ODTUjk multiplexing capacity is less than the ODUCn capacity as noted in Table 1. For example, an ODUC6 uses six logical slices and supports up to 300G of LO ODTUjk multiplexing.

Automatic assignment of the ODTUjk multiplexing instances to the MO ODUk signals by the SDK can also be used by the NMS when the network planner knows the MO ODUk signals are known to always be of the same type. This use-case supports non-blocking LO ODTUjk multiplexing up to the capacity of the ODUCn since de-provisioning the MO ODUk will always result in tributary slots being available in a ODTUjk multiplexing instance the next time a LO ODUk is provisioned from a MO ODUk of the same type. For example, for an application where an ODUC3 is known to always be composed of 30 x ODU2 signals, automatic assignment of the logical ODTUjk multiplexing instance can be used by the NMS and the non-blocking LO ODTUjk multiplexing capacity is 300G (i.e. the full ODUCn capacity).

Manual assignment of the ODTUjk multiplexing instances to the MO ODUk signals by the SDK can be used in certain scenarios where the composition of the MO ODUk signals within the ODUCn is known in advance. A network application may provision an ODUCn that will always contain a known mix of MO ODUk signals. For example, the application may require a OTUC3 that will contain either 20 x ODU2 and 1 x ODU4 or 20 x ODU2 and 10 x ODU2. In this case, the NMS can use a fixed assignment of the logical ODTUjk multiplexing instances that are used when provisioning the LO ODUk signals that are multiplexed from the MO ODUk signals. The LO ODUk signals multiplexed into the ODU4 / ODU2 signals would have a fixed assignment to one logical ODTUjk multiplexing instance by the NMS and two logical ODTUjk multiplexing instances would be used for the LO ODUk signals that are multiplexed into the 20 x ODU2 signals. The LO ODTUjk multiplexing capacity of the ODUC3 is 300G with the caveat the 10 x ODU2 signals assigned to the same ODTUjk multiplexing instance block provisioning of the ODU4.

For both manual and automatic assignment methods, the SDK always allocates the same logical ODTUjk multiplexing instances that are available for ODTUjk multiplexing from the OTUCn depending on the size of the OTUCn. The logical ODTUjk multiplexing resources and defined by the info.logical_slice argument to the g5_api_odu_mux_cfg() API. The logical slice argument is an enumerated type g5_cn_mux_jk_mux_instance_t with values as per Table 1 .

table.title: Logical ODTUjk Multiplexing Slice Enumerated Type Definitions

entry.p: Logical 1st JK instance within the ODUCn group channel
Logical 2nd JK instance within the ODUCn group channel
Logical 3rd JK instance within the ODUCn group channel
Logical 4th JK instance within the ODUCn group channel
Logical 5th JK instance within the ODUCn group channel
Logical 6th JK instance within the ODUCn group channel

body.p: The pool of logical ODTUjk multiplexing instances that is assigned for LO multiplexing by the SDK for each ODUCn type is shown in Table 2. The fixed assignment of ODTUjk resources is done by the SDK when the OTUCn is provisioned and is always the same. For example, an ODUC2 is always allocated the first and second ODTUjk multiplexing instances and a ODUC3 is always allocated the first through third instances.

table.title: SDK Allocated Pool of Logical ODTUjk Multiplexing Instances Available for LO ODUk Multiplexing by ODUCn Type

entry.p: SDK Allocated Pool of Logical ODTUjk Multiplexing Instances

body.p: In the case of automatic assignment of ODTUjk multiplexing instances to a MO ODUk when a LO ODUk is provisioned, the SDK will select the instance to use from the pool of instances assigned to the ODUCn when the OTUCn is provisioned. Automatic assignment is configured by the NMS by using G5_CN_MUX_JK_MUX_AUTO as the info.logic_slice_argument to the g5_api_odu_mux_cfg() API when a LO is provisioned. Automatic assignment is the default behavior if the info.logic_slice_argument is not specified.

In the case of explicit or manual assignment, the NMS can assign the logical ODTUjk multiplexing instance for a ODUCn MO ODUk when the LO ODUk is provisioned by calling the g5_api_odu_mux_cfg() API with the jk_logical_instance argument specifying the logical JK multiplexing instance to use from the pool of instances allocated by the SDK. If an attempt is made to assign a MO ODUk to a logical slice that is not within the fixed pool of ODTUjk multiplexing instances assigned to the OTUCn when it is provisioned, a SEGMENT_ODTUJK_SUBCONTAINER_JK_MUX_INST_NOT_IN_GROUP error is generated. For example, for an ODUC4, an attempt to use G5_CN_MUX_5TH_JK_MUX when calling the g5_api_odu_mux_cfg() API to provision a LO ODUk would result in a SEGMENT_ODTUJK_SUBCONTAINER_JK_MUX_INST_NOT_IN_GROUP error message since the SDK always allocates logical JK multiplexing instances G5_CN_MUX_1ST_JK_MUX through G5_CN_MUX_4TH_JK_MUX for use by a ODUC4.
The SDK behavior of interest when planning how the NMS will manage the LO ODTUjk multiplexing behavior is dictated by two APIs.

li.p: The info.jk_logical_slice argument to the g5_api_odu_mux_cfg() API defines if the SDK will automatically assign ODTUjk multiplexing instances or if they are explicitly assigned by the NMS.

The enable argument to the g5_api_jk_muxing_non_blocking_set(). By default (or if the API is called with the enable argument set to true), the SDK will generate a CALENDAR_MGR_CN_MUX_JK_MUX_NON_BLOCKING_LIMIT_EXCEEDED and perform no provisioning if the non-blocking capacity of the ODUCn is exceeded when a LO ODUk is provisioned.

body.p: Table 3 defines the use-cases for the two APIs.

table.title: ODUCn Automatic and Manual LO ODTUjk Provisioning

entry.p: LO ODUk from ODUCn are multiplexed from MO ODUk of arbitrary composition
LO ODUk from ODUCn are multiplexed from MO ODUk of the same type
LO ODUk from ODUCn contains a known MO ODUk blocking scenario that is managed by the NMS and disclosed in end-user documentation
ODUCn: n x 100G with NMS managed blocking scenarios
NMS specifies logical instance when LO ODUk signals are provisioned

body.p: For use case 1, the SDK algorithm guarantees non-blocking provisioning of ODTUjk multiplexing instances for LO ODUk signals up to the bandwidth limits noted in the maximum LO ODUk non-blocking capacity column. The provisioning sequence is as follows.

li.p: Call the g5_api_jk_muxing_non_blocking_set() API prior to datapath provisioning with an enable argument of TRUE.

Call the g5_api_api_otucn_group_prov(), g5_api_otucn_port_add() and g5_api_otucn_group_config() APIs to provision the OTUCn port. The SDK will allocate a pool of ODTUjk multiplexing instances to the OTUCn group as perTable 2 .
Use G5_CN_MUX_JK_MUX_AUTO for the info.jk_logical_slice argument to the g5_api_odu_mux_cfg() call when provisioning the LO ODUk signals.

body.p: For use case 2, provisioning of the LO ODUk signals will not block since the MO ODUk are always of the same type. The maximum LO ODUk capacity for a ODUCn will be n x 100G. For example, an ODUC3 with 30 x ODU2 MO signals will not block when provisioning LO signals. The provisioning sequence for case 2 is the same as case 1 except the the non-blocking limit exceeded error generation needs to be disabled by calling the g5_api_jk_muxing_non_blocking_set() API with the enable argument set to false. Refer to the g5_1xotuc2_2xodu4_20xodu2_10ge_ilkn_pif.c source code in the SDK examples directory for an example of implementing use case 2.

The g5_api_cn_grp_jk_alloc_get() API can be used to report the current resource allocation on each ODTUjk instance that is reserved for the ODUCn group channel. The API also returns the total number of free tributary slots in an ODUCn group. The g5_1xotuc2_2xodu4_20xodu2_10ge_ilkn_pif.c file in the sdk/examples directory provides an example of using the g5_api_cn_grp_jk_alloc_get() API to report the logical ODTUjk multiplexing instance use.
Example output after the first 10 x ODU2 are provisioned is as follows.
body.codeblock: ############## Cn Group ODTUjk Allocation ############## ### grp_free_slots: 80 ### ### jk_inst_free_slots[0]: 16 ### ### jk_inst_free_slots[1]: 96 ### ### jk_inst_free_slots[2]: 255 ### ### jk_inst_free_slots[3]: 255 ### ### jk_inst_free_slots[4]: 255 ### ### jk_inst_free_slots[5]: 255 ###
body.p: Example output after the second 10 x ODU2 are provisioned is as follows.
body.codeblock: ############## Cn Group ODTUjk Allocation (after 2nd ODU4) ############ ### grp_free_slots: 0 ### ### jk_inst_free_slots[0]: 16 ### ### jk_inst_free_slots[1]: 16 ### ### jk_inst_free_slots[2]: 255 ### ### jk_inst_free_slots[3]: 255 ### ### jk_inst_free_slots[4]: 255 ### ### jk_inst_free_slots[5]: 255 ###
body.p: The grp_free_slots output reports the number of total free tributary slots in the ODUCn group in 1.25G units. jk_inst_free_slots_ptr is a pointer to an array of 6 x UINT32 where each element of the array represents the number of free tributary slots in each ODTUjk instance in 1.25G units. The maximum possible free slots in each ODTUjk instance is 96 (120G). The maximum possible free slots for a ODUCn is n x 80 over the n JK multiplexing instances that are allocated to the ODUCn.

Use case 3 consists of a known LO ODUk composition with blocking scenarios the NMS manages. The use case requires manual assignment of the ODTUk multiplexing instances. Figure 12 illustrates an example of use case 3. The example is an ODUC4 that can supports a composition of MO ODUk signals that is either 30 x ODU2 + 1 x ODU4 or 30 x ODU2 + 10 x ODU2 signals.

This use case 3 example requires end-user documentation to disclose the use-cases that avoid blocking scenarios when the NMS manages assignment of LO ODUk signals to logical ODTUjk multiplexing instances. In this case, the NMS assigns 10 of the ODU2 signals and the ODU4 signal to the same logical ODTUjk multiplexing instance. End user documentation would specify these 10 ODU2 signals would need to be de-provisioned prior to provisioning an ODU4 (and vice versa). The NMS assigns the 30 ODU2 signals to the remaining three logical ODTUjk multiplexing instances that are available for the ODUC3. End user documentation would specify these 30 ODU2 signals support non-blocking provisioning of LO ODUk signals. The maximum LO ODUk capacity for the ODUC4 is 400G in this application with the caveat regarding the blocking scenarios. The provisioning sequence requires the logical ODTUjk multiplexing instances to be specified and the blocking error message to be disabled.

li.p: Call the g5_api_jk_muxing_non_blocking_set() API prior to datapath provisioning with an enable argument of FALSE.

Call the g5_api_api_otucn_group_prov(), g5_api_otucn_port_add() and g5_api_otucn_group_config() APIs to provision the OTUCn port. The SDK will allocate a pool of ODTUjk multiplexing instances to the OTUCn group.

Use G5_CN_MUX_1ST_JK_MUX to G5_CN_MUX_3RD_JK_MUX for the info.jk_logical_slice argument to the g5_api_odu_mux_cfg() when provisioning LO ODUk signals from the 30 x MO ODU2 signals that are not ear-marked to block provisioning of the ODU4.

Use G5_CN_MUX_4TH_JK_MUX for the info.jk_logical_slice argument to the g5_api_odu_mux_cfg() when provisioning the LO ODUk signals from the 10 x ODU2 or ODU4 that are documented in end user documentation as blocking .

fig.title: ODUCn Manual LO ODTUjk Multiplexing Instance Assignment Example

body.p: As noted in the above examples, the maximum line side OTN capacity of 500G or 600G is dependent on the datapaths that are provisioned. The SDK will accept or reject 600G of LINEOTN I/F or 500G of LINEOTN I/F with two stages of ODTUjk multiplexing based on the configuration request and the current state of configured resources. The SDK does not provide an API that selects between a 500G or 600G mode. The SDK will not allow a logical ODTUjk multiplexing instance to be used for more than one OTU4 port or more than one OTUCn group. Only the 2nd stage ODTUjk multiplexing instance allows for the MOs to be sourced from any of the other five ODTUjk multiplexing instances. All other ODTUjk multiplexing instances must source their HO data from one OTU4 port or any of the tributary slots within an OTUCn group.

The SDK will allow provisioning of a 2nd stage of ODTUjk multiplexing provided 500G or less of LINEOTN I/F ports are provisioned. If not an error code SEGMENT_ODTUJK_SUBCONTAINER_JK_MUX_INST_UNAVAILABLE is returned and no configuration is performed. The SDK will allow provisioning of an OTU4 port or an OTUCn group that will create LINEOTN I/F bandwidth of 600G provided a 2nd stage od ODTUjk multiplexing is not allocated to an existing OTU4 port's MO. If not a SEGMENT_ODTUJK_SUBCONTAINER_JK_MUX_INST_UNAVAILABLE error code is returned. The SDK will allocate a logical ODTUjk multiplexing instance to every 100G of LINEOTN I/F bandwidth that is provisioned. An OTU4 Port will be allocated 1 ODTUjk multiplexing instance for potential future provisioning of payload multiplexing. An OTUCn Group will be allocated n JODTUjk multiplexing instances for potential future provisioning of payload multiplexing. The logical ODTUjk multiplexing instances that are allocated by the SDK to an OTUCn are fixed. The SDK manages the physical ODTUjk multiplexing instance associated with the logical instance as noted earlier.
